title: Modules & structure
text:
Section · Structure


Suggested modules & folders


The exact layout of the repository is intentionally flexible. The structure below represents a lightweight organisation that works well for both teaching exercises and rapid research prototyping.




Codes in R


scripts/
Basic radiative transfer examples using ToolsRTM and SCOPEinR, including single-run scripts, parameter sweeps, and small lookup table (LUT) generators. These scripts are intended for rapid experimentation, method testing, and teaching, and can be run independently or used as building blocks for more advanced workflows, notebooks, or Shiny applications.




Shiny apps


apps/
Interactive Shiny applications that link biochemical and structural plant traits to simulated spectra. These apps are designed for rapid exploration of model behaviour, and interactive teaching and prototyping. They allow users to adjust key biophysical parameters in real time, visualise spectral and physiological responses across different radiative transfer models.




Lookup tables


LUTs/
The Lookup tables and input parameter files used to run different radiative transfer and eco-physiological models within the Virtual Biophysical Lab. The LUTs support multiple modelling frameworks, including leaf-, canopy-, and top-of-atmosphere simulations (e.g. PROSAIL, INFORM, FLUSPECT, Liberty, SCOPE), and are used to ensure reproducibility and consistency across scripts.




Notebooks


notebooks/
R or Python notebooks used for interactive exploration, teaching demonstrations, and quick checks of model behaviour.




Figures


assets/
logos, plots and diagrams generated by the lab, designed for reuse in lectures, presentations, or scientific papers.




Docs


docs/
Short notes, mini-tutorials, and descriptions of example scripts or exercises intended for students and new users.

title: Status
text:
Section · Status


●Early prototype / sandbox


The Virtual Biophysical Lab is currently in an early prototype phase. Its primary objective is to provide a clean, low-friction environment for testing methodological ideas, hosting small and reproducible examples for students and collaborators, and preparing content that can later be migrated into more complete tools or project-specific repositories.


At this stage, the emphasis is on clarity, reproducibility, and pedagogical value rather than on operational completeness. Interfaces, examples, and documentation may evolve rapidly as concepts are validated, refined, and consolidated.

Getting started with the repository


This section provides a minimal workflow to help you start using the Virtual Biophysical Lab repository for learning, teaching, or early-stage research prototyping.



Clone the repository locally or download it as a ZIP archive.


Open the notebooks/ or rtm/ directories in your preferred IDE (e.g. RStudio, VS Code).


Run one of the introductory scripts and modify key parameters such as LAI, chlorophyll content (Cab), or soil brightness.


Visualise the outputs and compare results across scenarios, stress levels, or sensor configurations.

title: ToolsRTM
text:
Section · Simulation tool


ToolsRTM


The Virtual Biophysical Lab is designed to connect with existing R toolboxes for radiative transfer modelling. The ToolsRTM package provides a comprehensive suite of models for simulating leaf and canopy reflectance, including soil and atmosphere components.



ToolsRTM


Leaf & canopy radiative transfer


ToolsRTM is an R package designed to perform detailed simulations of leaf and canopy reflectance using a wide suite of radiative transfer (RT) models. It operates across multiple satellite spectral configurations and enables high-fidelity analysis of vegetation biophysical and biochemical traits.


At the canopy level, ToolsRTM includes models such as INFORM, fourSAIL, and fourSAIL2, enabling the simulation of BRDF-sensitive canopy reflectance under variable structural and illumination conditions.


At the leaf level, the package integrates models such as PROSPECT, Liberty, and FLUSPECT (B–Cx), enabling simulation of pigment content, water, and dry matter effects on reflectance and transmittance.


ToolsRTM also incorporates the SPART model for TOA simulations, integrating:



BSM – soil reflectance


PROSAIL – canopy reflectance


SMAC – atmospheric radiative transfer



The package includes the MARMIT model for bare-soil reflectance (400–2500 nm), implemented via get.marmit1 and get.marmit2.


ToolsRTM provides access to eight reference soil and vegetation databases used for model parameterisation and validation.


GitLab repository: ToolsRTM package





R · ToolsRTM


Shiny application and LUT example


Example R code showing how to launch the RT simulators and generate a small PROSAIL LUT using ToolsRTM.

title: SCOPEinR
text:
Section · Simulation tool


SCOPEinR


SCOPEinR provides an R interface to the SCOPE model, enabling coupled simulations of radiative transfer, photosynthesis, and energy balance. It is particularly suited for studying canopy stress responses, energy partitioning, and fluorescence dynamics across environmental conditions.



SCOPEinR


Coupled radiative transfer & energy balance

SCOPEinR is an R package implementing the Soil Canopy Observation, Photochemistry and Energy Fluxes (SCOPE) model, originally developed in MATLAB by Van der Tol et al. (2009) and further extended by Yang et al. (2020). The package enables simulations of interactions between radiation, vegetation canopies, soil, and the atmosphere within a single, coupled radiative transfer and energy balance framework.


SCOPEinR also powers the online RT-Simulator, providing a Shiny-based interface that allows users to simulate top-of-canopy (TOC) reflectance, canopy temperature, and chlorophyll fluorescence emissions under variable meteorological and structural conditions. This makes the package particularly useful for analysing vegetation stress, energy partitioning, and photochemical efficiency.


For systematic intercomparison with other radiative transfer (RT) models, SCOPEinR can be used together with ToolsRTM, enabling parallel simulations across different RT formulations (leaf-level, canopy-level, and RTM-based flux retrievals).


Within the Virtual Biophysical Lab, SCOPEinR can be used to:



Simulate canopy fluxes, temperature, TOC reflectance, fluorescence (SIF), and energy balance.


Compare environmental scenarios such as drought, heat stress, stomatal closure, or nutrient limitation.


Generate synthetic diurnal cycles for benchmarking against flux-tower observations (e.g. GPP, LE, Rn).


Support forward simulations for evaluating RT parameterisations and hybrid machine-learning inversion pipelines.



The SCOPEinR and ToolsRTM packages are being integrated into an online RT-platform (currently in testing), providing real-time simulations and visualisations through an interactive interface.


GitLab repositories: SCOPEinR package  Online RT-platform (Shiny RT-Simulator) 


Note: These modules are currently in a testing phase prior to public release.

title: Use cases
text:
Section · Use cases


What can you do in this lab?


The Virtual Biophysical Lab is intentionally compact, yet it supports both teaching-oriented activities and early-stage research prototyping. Typical use cases include:




Teaching


Simple exercises
Short, self-contained scripts can be used for practical exercises on leaf and canopy properties (e.g. LAI and chlorophyll effects), stress versus control scenarios, or comparisons between simulated spectra and satellite sensor bands. These examples are well suited for MSc-level courses and introductory training.




Prototyping


Idea testing
The lab provides a lightweight environment to rapidly test new vegetation indices, perform sensitivity analyses, or explore alternative inversion strategies before integrating them into larger project repositories or operational processing pipelines.




Communication


Figures & mini-demos
Users can generate figures or small interactive demonstrations that illustrate model behaviour, assumptions, and limitations for presentations, project meetings, or internal documentation.

title: Overview
text:
What are these tutorials?
The HYDRA-EO tutorial platform mirrors the structure of the main HYDRA-EO project website, but in a lightweight scientific format. It provides a sandbox where users can interact with radiative transfer models, explore spectral simulations, test machine-learning workflows and understand how symptoms of crop stress emerge across spectral domains.



RTMs


Radiative transfer simulations
Hands-on examples using ToolsRTM (PROSAIL, INFORM, FLUSPECT, SPART, MARMIT) and SCOPEinR for coupled radiative transfer, energy balance and fluorescence.




Hybrid ML


Trait-based machine learning
Practical workflows showing how synthetic RTM libraries can support supervised learning, stress differentiation and band/feature selection for ESA missions.




EO


Multi-sensor Earth Observation
Use cases combining UAV hyperspectral, thermal, airborne HyPlant, and satellite data (Sentinel-2, PRISMA, EnMAP, FLEX-like SIF) to explore scaling from leaf to landscape.

title: Tutorials
text:
This section provides the practical learning layer of the Virtual Biophysical Lab. It gathers structured tutorials that translate the scientific concepts, models, and workflows developed in HYDRA-EO into reproducible, hands-on examples.
The tutorials are organised by core modelling packages used within the project, primarily ToolsRTM and SCOPEinR, and are delivered as executable notebooks and scripted workflows that can be directly run, modified, and reused.

title: Tutorials
text:
TooslRTM package
The ToolsRTM tutorials introduce the foundations of radiative transfer modelling and EO-based plant trait retrieval. They guide users through leaf- and canopy-level reflectance simulations, spectral sensitivity analysis and band selection, and the integration of radiative transfer models with Earth Observation data. Emphasis is placed on hybrid workflows that combine physically based models with machine-learning approaches. The tutorials are implemented as step-by-step notebooks, making them suitable both for self-learning and for use in teaching and training activities.

title: Tutorials
text:
SCOPE package
The SCOPE tutorials focus on the simulation of coupled energy balance, photosynthesis, and fluorescence processes at the canopy scale. They demonstrate how SIF and thermal signals can be interpreted in relation to underlying physiological processes, and how model outputs can be validated against field measurements and flux-tower observations. Together, the ToolsRTM and SCOPE tutorials form a coherent modelling pathway, linking radiative transfer fundamentals with ecosystem-scale interpretation and validation.
